headline: CNN News Central
subHeadline: Key Witness Testifies Amid Effort To Boot Trump Prosecutor. Aired 3-3:30p ET

utterances.speaker: ASHLEIGH MERCHANT, DEFENSE ATTORNEY FOR MIKE ROMAN
utterances.sentences: And then we spoke after Mr. Wade called, your friend, and we talked about that as well, correct?TERRENCE BRADLEY, NATHAN WADE'S FORMER LAW PARTNER & DIVORCE ATTORNEY: That is correct.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And at that point you didn't mention anything to me about being represented by Mr. Chopra.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: But I didn't mention anything about Mr. Chopra or - that is correct.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Yes, that was only my question.Let's see. I'm going to show you two more texts (inaudible) ...

utterances.speaker: JUDGE SCOTT MCAFEE, FULTON COUNTY SUPERIOR COURT
utterances.sentences: All right. Ms. Merchant, we're going to do five more minutes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: This is the last two questions, thank you.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Thank you. May I approach? I'm going to show you a full text to refresh your memory (inaudible) ...

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Are these supposed to go together?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: All these are two separate dates?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Absolutely different dates.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Okay. All right.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So I know we talked on a number of occasions where you said the text was just about the footnote. But do you recall me asking you, do you think it started before she hired him? And you said, absolutely. Do you recall that?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I see that in the text message, yes.   MERCHANTreact, if they would attack me. And you said, no, they will deny it.

utterances.speaker: ADAM ABBATE
utterances.sentences: Your Honor, objection as to speculation, as to how he thinks they will react.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: I think it goes to the motivations of the witness, overruled.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And you told me that they will deny it.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's written in there. Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I just want to - one last opportunity. You're an officer of the court, correct?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And you're under oath today?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Is there any of your testimony from today or the previous days that you want to correct?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: That I want to correct?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: No, I've told you everything that you've - I've answered everything that you asked.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Oh, Judge, just so the counsel and the state can have them, the - just for the record, I can admit those few that (inaudible) ...

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Well, they weren't ever tendered.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And, Judge (inaudible) ...

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: So just for ...

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I didn't know if they wanted to use them.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: But I'll hold on to them.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: If they need to be tendered at some point, then we'll make them part of the record.All right. Any - let me turn it over to Mr. Sadow, if you're with us on Zoom. STEVE SADOW, DONALD TRUMP'S DEFENSE ATTORNEY: Thank you, Your Honor. I do have a few questions. First thing I'd like to know is whether the court reporter has defense exhibits 26 and 27 from the last ...

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: We have a different court reporter this time. We had to have someone else fill in on such short notice. But I can potentially send those to you if you need them.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Well, I think I have working copies, but I want to make sure that the witness has a copy to look at.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. We can try to work through that logistical challenge. This is - you said 26 and 27?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I believe that's correct. And 26, I think, is the same text messages that Ms. Merchant was just asking about. It was two pages. I stapled it together and it is dated January the 5th of this year.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. I can print off a copy now, but why don't we start off with the questions that you have.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay, because ...

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: I can do it.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: ... that's where I want to start. That's where I'm going to start. But I'll see what I can do to work through it.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Is that going to work? Here, I'll email them to you. Okay.All right, Mr. Sadow, why don't we start with your question and we'll see if we actually need to get a copy of those exhibits in front of the witness.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: All right. Mr. Bradley?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, I'm here.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I'm here. I can hear you.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Yes. No, I know. I think his visuals may be a little different. So hold on tight, Mr. Sadow. We could try to correct that.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Yes, he was on when Ms. Merchant was asking questions.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Just - we need to add a ...

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: (Inaudible) ...

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: I know, we need to add a spotlight to mister - to the witness stand and a spotlight to Mr. Sadow, and we don't need all the other boxes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: There we go. Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Well, then hold on tight, Mr. Sadow, we need to add you as well.All right. Now we're ready.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you, sir.Mr. Bradley, you have referred to Mr. Wade as your client, correct?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: You understand that the court has ruled that communications that you had with Mr. Wade are not privileged, correct?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: No, I'm aware that the court ruled that one specific dealing with the time frame of one specific conversation wasn't privileged.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Then I'm going to ask, Your Honor, if it's at the limitation or ...

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Excuse me. The - to clarify ...

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: ... (inaudible) ...

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: ... sure. Mr. Sadow, you asked whether all communications with Mr. Wade, I think, were covered. That was not the extent of the ruling. The only ones that I deemed were not covered and that I'd asked about in the in-camera hearing because those are the ones that were relevant, were any communications Mr. Wade made regarding the existence or nonexistence of a romantic relationship with Ms. Willis.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Fine. Thank you, Your Honor. I understand.So going back to this line of inquiry, when you say you don't have personal knowledge, what I want to ask you to start with is very simple, did you have communications with Mr. Wade about the relationship between Mr. Wade and Ms. Willis? It's a simple yes and no.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. And is it your testimony that during the time you were representing him, which I understood started sometime in 2018, is that correct?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: That's the time frame that I remember, yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. Is it your testimony under oath that with regards to conversations with Mr. Wade about his relationship with Ms. Willis, that you only had one such conversation during the time you represented Mr. Wade?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: One conversation of what? I apologize, you broke off ...

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: The only thing we're - I'm - the only thing I'm asking about is that area that the court said is not privileged, which is the relationship between Mr. Wade and Ms. Willis. You've testified that during the time you represented Mr. Wade from 2018 on, that you only had one conversation with him in reference to the relationship between Ms. Willis and Mr. Wade, is that correct?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, I think that's fairly accurate. Yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. So out of the entire time talking about it, it could be 2018, 2019, 2020, 2021, when did you stop representing Mr. Wade?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: It was a few months after I left the firm.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: All right. Give me an approximate time.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I left maybe June - July of 2022, maybe.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. So that would suggest that for - assuming it's 2018 - 2018, 2019, 2020, 2021 and half of 2022, which is in the vicinity of four to four and a half years, you're testifying under oath you had one conversation about a relationship between Mr. Wade and Ms. Willis. Is that correct?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I don't recall having any other conversation with Mr. Wade about him and Ms. Willis.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Is it your testimony, then, that you don't remember any other conversation or there wasn't any other conversation besides the one?

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: (Inaudible) object as to the answer ...

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: I think he's drilling down. I think that's a fair question, overruled.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: You testified that you did have communications with Mr. Wade about him visiting with Ms. Willis at a condo or apartment, correct?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I don't think I testified that I had a conversation. I testified that any knowledge that I would have known anything about any condo would have come from that, but I don't recall a conversation about that. I do not recall a conversation about that.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. Do you recall any other thing at this point in time under oath that would indicate when the relationship started between Mr. Wade and Ms. Willis?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I do not know when the relationship started between Mr. Wade and Ms. Willis. I cannot recall that. I can't ...

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: (Inaudible) ...

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry, go ahead.   SADOW

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Mr. Wade was hired as the special prosecutor on November 1st of 2021. You're aware of that, correct?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I have my contracts to show when I started. No one showed me the contract of when he started, but - so - but if he has a contract for November 1st of 2021, then that's correct.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: All right. I'm going to suggest to you that the record will reflect that the contract between Ms. Willis and Mr. Wade was November 1st of 2021, correct? I want you just to accept that, okay?Is it your testimony that you don't know under oath whether or not there was a relationship between Mr. Wade and Ms. Willis before the contract?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I do not recall any dates of when the relationship started. So whether you are pinpointing a date of when his contract started or not, I'm telling you I did not recall any specific date that he flat out said anything about a relationship with Ms. Willis.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. Now I want to go, based on what you've just said, let's go to what was defense exhibit 26, okay? In defense exhibit 26, which I showed you last time, it was two pages of text messages between you and Ms. Merchant, correct?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: All right. Now, the first page starts off by saying, "Ms. Merchant, like just date, don't hire him. Do you think it started before she hired him?" You see that?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, I see it. Yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And your response to that was absolutely, correct?

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: I'm going to object (inaudible) ...

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. So Mr. Sadow, I do think we went through a lot of these texts.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: We didn't go through this whole one.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Just a second, Mr. Sadow.All right. I'm sorry, Mr. Sadow. You said we didn't go through this particular one?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: No. We went through - we stopped right there. I want to go ...

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I went - I answered, because she - this is the exact language that she just stated a few minutes ago. You can read it back from the record.   MCAFEEweren't already covered by Ms. Merchant?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: It was not gone - this particular language was not gone into. I'm doing it based on the exhibit itself. Well, let's do it this way, I now move into evidence defense exhibit number 26.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. And I don't have - I'd have to search through my notes, but does anyone recall, that one actually been tendered in a minute already?

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: It was.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: No, it was only presented to Your Honor for you to take back into camera ex parte to speak with Mr. Bradley and his counsel.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Okay. Ms. Merchant is indicating that it was admitted.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I thought Mr. Sadow admitted it, but I'm organizing of bringing them back in order, so I think it might be easier if I just admit the copies of the texts ...

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: ... we're all referring to.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. So defense exhibit 26 and 27 are being tendered.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Actually, only 26 at this time.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Okay. You - okay, defense exhibit 6, any objection from the state?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Twenty-six.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Twenty-six.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Okay. As to foundation and authentication, I think Mr. Bradley has recognized them as texts that he sent and received, so I think I'd overrule on that basis. Any other objections to their admissibility from any other defense counsel. And seeing none, defense exhibit 26 is now admitted, Mr. Sadow.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you.All right, let's continue.   Now I'm publishing it. After you said the word absolutely, on your own, you said it started when she left the DA's office and was judge in South Fulton.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: (Inaudible) ...

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: They met at ...

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: ... object ...

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: Asked and answered.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. Understood, Mr. Abbate. I'm going to let Mr. Sadow have a few minutes on this and we'll go from there, but ...

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Judge, I - well, I'm sorry. I did answer this. I answered it for Ms. ...

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: I understand.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: ... Merchant. I stated that I was speculating. The Judge - someone objected to the speculation, and - but this was the exact same language when I said that.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. Well, thank you for that, Mr. Bradley. Mr. Sadow is asking the question in a slightly different manner and I'm going to give him a little bit of leeway to do that. So, Mr. Sadow.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: All right. I hesitate to have to start back where I was, but after the word absolutely, you, on your own, said it started when she left the DA's office and was judge in South Fulton. They met at the municipal court CLE conference. That's what you said, correct?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: That is correct.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Now, it's your testimony, at least so far, that when you, on your own, gave those two statements in the text, that you were merely speculating and did not have that knowledge from Mr. Wade. Is that your testimony under oath?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's what I testified to, yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: So, you, on your own, came up with the whole notion that it started when she left the DA's office and was judge in South Fulton. That's - according to you, that's speculation on your part, correct?

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: Objection (inaudible) ...

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Overruled. Answer the question, Mr. Bradley.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's speculation on my part, yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Right. It had nothing to do with what Mr. Wade had told you, correct?   BRADLEYThat is correct.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: So, maybe you can tell the court, in your own words, why in the heck would you speculate in this text message and say that it started when she left the DA's office and was a judge in South Fulton? Why would you speculate and say that in a text?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I knew they had met at the municipal court conference.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: How do you know that? I'll stop you right there. How did you know that?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I answered that the last - at the last - I knew that ...

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I'm asking you now ...

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I knew that because when ...

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: ... sir, I'm asking you now. I'm asking questions and you are in a situation where you get to give answers. I'm asking you, how did you know that?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: How did I know when they met?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Some people - somebody told you that, right?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: When they met?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, correct.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Who told you?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Mr. Wade told me when they met.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: So, you had more than one conversation about the relationship between Mr. Wade and Ms. Willis because he told you where he met her, correct?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: That's incorrect. Incorrect.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: It's incorrect?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: It's incorrect.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: But - okay, let's go back to ...

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: He ...

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: ... let's go back to the exhibit. Why would you speculate that that's when they started the relationship? What would cause you to put that down as speculation?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I don't recall but why I thought that it started at that time, but I do recall that he only met her and I testified to that, that he met her in - at that conference which was in 2019.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: You knew that Ashleigh Merchant represented a defendant in this case when you were text messaging with her, correct?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, I did. Yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And you knew that the reason she was asking you questions about Mr. Wade was because she was trying to show when the relationship began, correct?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: No, that's not 100 percent correct.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, but what messages were before this message, before she sent that?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I can't answer that question because I don't have them. All I have is what's in front of you.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And it said - that she says, "Do you think it started before she hired him?" So you knew, as the counsel for a defendant in this case, that Ms. Merchant was asking you specifically about the knowledge that you had regarding the timing of the relationship between Wade and Ms. Willis, correct?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I mean, based on this, yes, I see what was asked.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And in response to that, you answered directly on your own what you now claim to be speculation, right?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: So I ask you one more time before I move to the next part of this. Why would you speculate when she was asking you a direct question about when the relationship started?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I have no answer for that.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Except for the fact that you do, in fact, know when it started and you don't want to testify to that in court.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Overruled.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: That's the best explanation, isn't it?

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: This is completely (inaudible) ...

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Overruled.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: That's the real, that's the true explanation because you don't want to admit it in court, correct?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: No, I have no direct knowledge of when the relationship started.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: You - I'm not going to go back through that again. Well, if you didn't know and you were asked specifically as this exhibit shows, maybe you can explain why you wouldn't say, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Is that a question? You're asking me a question to answer?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes, definite question.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: State that again, I apologize.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: If you're being asked, as we've just gone through with this text message from Mr. Merchant ...

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: ... as the attorney for a co-defendant ...

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And she's asking you about the relationship and she's clearly asking you about the timing, why wouldn't you just have said in response, I don't know when it started?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I don't know why I didn't say I don't know.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Maybe again, it's because you know what the truth is and that's why you answered exactly the way you did in defense exhibit 26, correct?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: No, I can't sit here and tell you that what you just stated was correct.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: What you want the court to believe and you want the rest of us to believe is that for some unknown reason, upon being asked a direct question about when the relationship started, you decided on your own to simply speculate and put it down in a text message as opposed to putting down what you actually knew. That's what you want the court to believe, correct?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: That was a lot. So can you break that down? I apologize. You're asking me, do I want the court to - the - just the ...

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: To believe that instead of saying nothing, you decided on your own to speculate.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, I speculated. Yes, I've stated that I speculated. Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. That's what you want the court to believe, correct?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: That's correct.   SADOWsee, it starts - the best that I can see, it starts in South Fulton. Is that what you have in front of you? Second page.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: The second page that I have says, "That's what I figured."

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. I - that may be cut off from the one that I have. The - it's - I'm looking at - my opening set - line says in South Fulton. Is that on your second page?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: No. So the - if you're going in order of the pages, no, neither page starts with South Fulton.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Now, my - don't get caught up on whether it starts that way. Does the second page have a line in there that it says in South Fulton?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes. I apologize. So, yes ...

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: That's fine.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Just want to make sure that we're on the same page.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's ...

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: You see that?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's correct.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And then Ms. Merchant says, "That's what I figured when he was married." Is this accurate upon information and belief? Willis and Wade met while both were serving as magistrate judges and began a romantic relationship at that time. You see, that's what she said, right?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: No. I mean - so it says they met at municipal court CLE. The only other thing here says, that's what I figured when he was married. There's no response from me on that day. And then there's another response - I mean, I guess a question that says, is this accurate.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. That's what I just went over with you.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Okay. So I don't have anything in that, is this accurate at all. I can show the court.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: (Inaudible) ...

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: It just says, is this accurate with the question mark? I don't have anything following that.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: You don't have, after that, upon information and belief, Willis and Wade met while both were serving as magistrate judges and began a romantic relationship at that time.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Okay. It's - I apologize. It goes to the next page. I apologize.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: No problem.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I just want to make sure that you're --

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: So, no - no, I see that now, yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: All right. So that's - what I just read is exactly what Ms. Merchant said to you in the text, right?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, that was in the text. Is it accurate upon further information? Yes, that's there. Yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And, again, since you have told us that you were speculating when you gave the answer that we went over with previously, on this one, you don't say, I don't know. You simply correct her by saying, no, municipal court, right?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes. So the - she asked, was it accurate? And I said, it wasn't accurate. No, it wasn't accurate. It was municipal court.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Right. And when you said it wasn't accurate, it was municipal court, you didn't say, no, that's not accurate. They didn't start a romantic relationship at that time, correct?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: No, but I was referring to the municipal court, no, it wasn't accurate as it applied to the - I was answering the no, municipal court. Meaning, if - when she said, is that accurate, it was to the municipal court and not magistrate court.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. But you didn't say that the rest of what she asked you was accurate. You didn't say, no, that's inaccurate. That's not true. That's not accurate. You simply said the only thing that wasn't accurate was municipal court should be there instead of magistrate, right?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: So I was answering the question of - it was a compound question ...

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay, can you (inaudible) ...

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: ... and I was answering the question of - she wrote magistrate court and I said, no, municipal court.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Right. But it's not compound. It's one statement ...

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. Mr. Sadow ...   SADOW

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: I know, that's okay. I know the feedback and the delays is - complicates things, but I think you've adequately made your point here. I don't think we need to belabor it much longer. Let's move on to the next issue.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. Thank you, Your Honor.Mr. Bradley, prior to coming into court today, did you and your lawyer meet with anyone from the district attorney's office?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: No. I mean, no.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Did your ...

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Not that I know - I'm aware of, no. I did not meet with anyone.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Sorry, I cut you off.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I did not meet with anyone outside of my attorneys.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Did you have any conversation about a meeting?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I did not.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: (Inaudible) conversation ...

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I did not.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: So you have not spoken, if I understand you correctly, prior to coming into court today, you've not spoken with the prosecutors?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Right?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I've not spoken to the prosecutors. I've not spoken to defense.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Have you spoken to Mr. Wade?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: So as far as just getting into the courtroom today, there's been no contact or conversation in it - with any of the parties we just went over, right?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: There has not been any contact with defense or the state at all.
